urn:contentItem:5M1F-K7X1-JCHV-V25F-00000-00Hedge Funds Love These 5 Stocks Right Now -- Should You?2016-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisHedge Funds Love These 5 Stocks Right Now -- Should You?Jonas Elmerraji

Pro investors have been piling into these five stocks in the third quarter. Here's everything you need to know.

Want an investing shortcut where the world's most prominent professional investors do the heavy lifting for you? All you need to do is follow the money.

Hedge funds have been net buyers of stocks again in 2016, but they've been much more selective than in years past. That's not totally surprising, considering the market environment we've been stuck in this year; the stats on the big S&P 500 index have been masking the fact that a big chunk of the market is actually working in 2016, and an equally big chunk of stocks are absolutely not working.

Put simply, stock picking still matters a lot this year,  so why not let the hedge funds pick the stocks for you?

Think of it like an investing shortcut. By leaving the hard analysis to the pros, you get all the perks of a well-staffed equity research department, without paying the hefty management fees the world's most successful hedge funds charge.

And believe it or not, you don't have to guess to figure out what the funds are buying right now. In fact, they'll tell you.

That's because institutional investors with more than $100 million in assets are required to file a 13F, a form that breaks down their stock positions for public consumption. From hedge funds to mutual funds to insurance companies, any professional investors who manage more than that $100 million watermark are required to submit a form 13F to the SEC.

Want to know which stocks are pro investors' favorites? Those 13F filings hold the key.

By comparing one quarter's filing to another, we can see how any single fund manager is moving their portfolio around. And by looking at those changes collectively, we can see which stocks the pros are betting on as a group. In other words, we can see which stocks Wall Street loves. While the data is generally delayed by about a quarter, that's not necessarily a bad thing. Research shows that applying a lag to institutional holdings can generate positive alpha in some cases. That's all the more reason to crack open the moves being made with pro investors' $21 trillion under management.

Because we're still relatively early in 13F filing season, consider this your sneak peek at the stocks hedge funds are buying. So, without delay, here's a closer look at five stocks fund managers love right now:


Alibaba

Leading things off on hedge funds' list of favorites this quarter is $260 billion Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba . Alibaba has been an outstanding performer in 2016, up almost 30% since the calendar flipped to January, so it's not totally out of left field that this big tech company is getting funds' attention. All told, early-filing funds added 12.6 million shares of Alibaba to their portfolios during the third quarter, a $1.3 billion buying operation at current share price levels.

Perhaps even more telling, that buying represented a 34% upsizing in those funds existing Alibaba positions from the prior quarter. That's a big conviction bet if there ever was one.

Alibaba is the biggest online commerce company on the planet, with 434 million active buyers and a gross merchandise volume that's expected to rise above $550 billion in 2016. That huge scale comes from an equally huge market -- Alibaba owns many of the most popular online marketplaces in China. Besides its namesake site, Alibaba's marketplaces include web marketplace Tmall, consumer-to-consumer sales site Taobao, and daily deals site Juhuasuan. Alibaba also operates the Alipay payment network, and a collection of smaller niche internet businesses.

At the same time, scores of U.S. e-commerce operators are working to push more business to mobile, China's demographics have been working in Alibaba's favor in a big way. The firm saw mobile sales account for about 65% of total merchandise value this past year, a massive share of the company's overall business that helps to ensure that consumers always have shopping available to them. Considering the fact that one in five Chinese consumers is presently an active shopper on one of the firm's websites, Alibaba's marketplaces have some major advantages over the competition. Shoppers use Alibaba because of its vast selection of products, and merchants sell on Alibaba's sites because it's where the shoppers are. That cycle makes Alibaba an attractive holding now, especially with buyers in control of shares this fall.


Amazon

Another one of funds' favorite stocks last quarter was U.S.-based e-commerce giant Amazon Are we sensing a theme here?

Amazon is another one of the world's biggest e-commerce companies. And while the firm's $205 billion in gross merchandise volume means that its scale is dramatically less than Alibaba's, it's still obviously a massive operator. Like its bigger peer, Amazon has been a notable outperformer in 2016, rallying more than 23% since the start of the year. That positive performance was good at catching hedge funds' attention. The first wave of pro investors added 738,000 shares of Amazon to their portfolios in the third quarter, a $616 million buying spree at current price levels.

Amazon's success story is built on scale and bridging the convenience gap between online retail and conventional brick-and-mortar retail. Not only does the firm use its scale and low-cost structure to move products more cheaply than competing sellers -- it also has gone to great lengths to reduce delivery times, most recently expanding its distribution infrastructure with new hubs in key markets. By adding services like Prime Video to its menu of offerings, the firm has increased customer stickiness in a way that pure price competitors can't touch.

Beyond its core retail business, Amazon has been building out a huge cloud computing operation that's grown into a material component of sales. Amazon Web Services reached $7.9 billion in revenues in 2015, and it's up to about $10 billion in the trailing four quarters. That entrée into higher-margin enterprise computing services should continue to be an attractive source of growth for Amazon, particularly as other big tech firms seek to hand off the challenges of building out a cloud infrastructure to an expert like Amazon.

Keep an eye out for Amazon's third quarter earnings results, set to hit Wall Street after the closing bell tomorrow.


JPMorgan Chase

The year 2016 has been treacherous for the financial sector. After starting off the year in free fall, financials have managed to more or less right themselves, with the exception of high-profile big banks like  Action Alerts PLUS holding Wells Fargo and Deutsche Bank , which have found themselves embroiled in scandal and financial crisis, respectively. But funds haven't been steering clear of the big banks in the last quarter. Instead, they piled into one of them.

Early filing funds picked up 2.13 million shares of JPMorgan Chase during the past quarter.

JPMorgan Chase is one of the biggest financial institutions, with more than $2.4 trillion in assets. Like the other big banking firms, JPMorgan operates a diversified financial services business, with operations in commercial and retail banking, asset management and treasury services, and investment banking. The past few years have been challenging for banking stocks, and while the smoke has largely cleared with respect to the fallout from the 2008 financial crisis, it doesn't change the fact that returns have been tamped down by increased regulatory scrutiny and low net interest margins.

The light at the end of the tunnel for investors in JPMorgan Chase is the Fed. A tiny rate hike in December looks very likely, bringing JPMorgan and its peers a little closer to the higher net interest margins that market participants have been hoping for. For that reason, JPM also makes a strong hedge this fall for income investors who have outsize exposure to big dividend payers.


iShares Russell 2000 ETF

Hedge funds weren't solely interested in stocks last quarter. The iShares Russell 2000 ETF was the sole exchange-traded fund that made the cut of the pros' favorite names for the third quarter of 2016. Funds added 3.93 million shares of IWM to their portfolios during the period.

Once again, the love for IWM looks like a case of chasing performance (on the surface, anyway). Year-to-date, this small-cap focused fund is up 7.4%, stomping the 4.8% price return found in the S&P 500. But for any strategists counting on small-cap outperformance for the rest of the year, the iShares Russell 2000 ETF is a pretty logical choice: it has exposure to 1,977 holdings (making it widely diversified, and trimming some of the headline risk that comes from owning a smaller portfolio of small-cap stocks), and relatively low fees.

After a pretty challenging couple of years for small-cap performance, IWM is overdue for some meaningful performance in 2016 -- and it's on track to make it happen. The fact that pro investors are buying up this big ETF makes it an especially interesting trade for investors looking to get a portfolio boost in the final stretch of the year.


Merck

Last up on our list of hedge funds' favorite stocks is pharmaceutical maker Merck . Merck is a drug giant, with more than $42 billion in sales last year. While Merck has been hit by a patent cliff just as hard as any of its other big pharma peers, the company's drug pipeline is one of the strongest in the industry. Relatively recent drugs like Januvia for diabetes, Keytruda for cancer, Isentress for HIV and anesthesia drug Bridion have the potential to be blockbusters for the company.

Merck is in good shape from a financial standpoint. The firm currently carries $23.7 billion in cash and investments, enough to offset nearly its entire $24 billion debt load. That ample cushion of financial reserves means that Merck is able to continue to make tactical purchases this year -- and that it's also able to continue boosting its 3% dividend payout.

This week's third-quarter earnings results were positive, leaving shares of Merck within grabbing distance of new 52-week highs this fall. Meanwhile, funds were fans of this stock in the most recent quarter, with early filers adding more than 275,000 shares of this stock to their aggregated portfolios. Look for a positive follow-up to Merck's earnings reaction in the trading sessions ahead.

urn:contentItem:5V0R-NDC1-F03R-N517-00000-00Hefty Fine Imposed On Facebook For "Misleading And Aggressive Practices"2018-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisHefty Fine Imposed On Facebook For "Misleading And Aggressive Practices"Mr Barış Yüksel LL.M., Fırat Eğrilmez, zlem Basiböyük LL.M. and Göke Kuranel LL.M.

Dec 19, 2018( Mondaq: http://www.mondaq.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In recent years, social media and technology companies have faced investigations initiated by competition and data protection authorities worldwide for violating data protection rules. It seems that competition and data protection enforcers are less hesitant to impose administrative fines, when it is believed that data protection or competition rules are violated by companies that utilize data as a part of their entrepreneurial activities1. In this respect, on 29 November 2018, Italian Competition Authority, Autorit Garante Della Concorrenza E Del Mercato ("AGCM") imposed an administrative fine against both Facebook Ireland Ltd. and its parent company Facebook Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "Facebook" collectively), on the grounds that the firm had undertaken misleading and aggressive practices affecting its users2.AGCM launched the probe leading to a hefty fine against Facebook in April, 2018 based on the concerns that articles 21, 22, 24 and 25 of the Italian Consumer Code ("Consumer Code") had been breached3. As per the assessments made through the course of the investigation, ACGM explains that Facebook was fined due to the its conducts listed below, which are alleged to be in contradiction with the said articles of the Consumer Code:Misleading the users in the sign-up process via a failure to explicitly indicate the purpose of data collection and specifying that the collected items would be utilized for commercial means by Facebook.Incentivizing the users to make decisions of a commercial nature without being granted access to the full facts, namely the profitable ends that could be achieved by Facebook via providing social network services to users.Undertaking an aggressive practice on registered users of Facebook by transmitting their data from the network to third parties and vice versa for achieving commercial purposes.With regards to the concerns about Article 21 and 22 of the Consumer Code, AGCM focuses on Facebook's misleading conduct against its users during the account creation phase.

AGCM points out that while the data required from Facebook users for the sign-up process is used for commercial purposes, Facebook do not provide adequate and immediate information to its users in relation with this purpose. Accordingly, AGCM sets forth that Facebook places an emphasis on the free nature of the services to induce its users to make a commercial decision that they would not have made otherwise, instead of revealing to the customers the commercial objectives underlying the provision of social network services. More specifically, Facebook's practice of emphasizing the "free of charge" nature of the social network services, is deemed as a misleading conduct that manipulates user decisions. Furthermore, AGCM has established that information provided by Facebook do not include a distinction per the functionality of the data collected and that it is incomplete. For instance, it is noted that Facebook do not inform its users whether the data would be used to personalize the network services or for advertising campaigns aimed at specific targets.In relation with the assessment made on Articles 24 and 25 of the Consumer Code, AGCM focuses on Facebook's conduct which is described as "aggressive practices", directed towards the registered consumers. Within this scope, AGCM expresses that the data obtained from the registered customers were being transmitted to third party websites or apps and vice versa for commercial purposes, without obtaining express and prior consent. Hence, by making its "active platform" function default, Facebook pre-sets its users' ability to access websites and external apps that use their Facebook accounts without their express consent. Accordingly, Facebook repeats the pre-selection mechanism whenever the user accesses a third-party website or an app, which is integrated with his or her Facebook account and merely provides an opt-out option. Considering the nature of this mechanism, AGCM indicated that Facebook's conduct induces unconscious and automatic consumer choice, on the ground that customers are not required to give an express and prior consent for data transmission.In further assessment, such conduct is characterized as an "undue influence", which stems from the pre-selection mechanism that ensures the broadest consumer consent to data sharing. AGCM ultimately establishes that, although registered consumers may limit their consent regarding the scope of data sharing, they are exposed to significant restrictions concerning the use of the social network, third-party websites and apps in a way that disincentivizes any potential variations of the pre-selected choice.Considering the foregoing, AGCM published a press release notifying that the investigation is concluded on 29 November 2018. In the press release it is declared that Facebook was fined 10 million Euros by AGCM for data misuse and that it was obliged to publish a correction statement on its app and website4.It is noteworthy to mention that it is not the first time that Facebook got in trouble with data protection rules. The company has previously been exposed to investigations in Ireland and the UK, with concerns regarding data protection rules. On 24 September 2018, Facebook engineers discovered that hackers were able to take over users' accounts and this led to a major scandal affecting nearly 50 million Facebook accounts. Consequently, the Irish Data Protection Commission initiated an investigation to examine whether Facebook complies with its obligations under General Data Protection Regulation ("GDPR")5.Facebook stated in its press releases that they were cooperating with the Irish Data Protection Commission since they realized such a security attack, the company has also been conducting an internal investigation and "continued to take remedial actions to mitigate the potential risks to users". In the wake of the Irish Data Protection Commission's announcement concerning the investigation, the Spanish Data Protection Agency stated that it would collaborate on the investigation for the rights of the Spanish citizens6.According to the GDPR, companies who fail to adequately protect relevant data could be fined for 20 million Euros or 4% of their global annual revenue from prior year, depending on which amount is greater. However, companies who notify the violation within three days will benefit from a reduction amounting to 2% of their global revenue. In this regard, the Irish Data Protection Commission reported that Facebook notified the breach on time to benefit from such reduction7. The investigation is not concluded yet and the potential fine that Facebook might face is estimated as $1.63bn, which is a considerable amount. The investigation is also crucial as it is considered as the first major test of Europe's new rules8.In the UK, Facebook was fined for 500.000 GBP on 25 October 2018, when old data privacy rules of the EU were still in force, which allowed for a maximum amount of fine of 500,000 GBP by Information Commissioner's Office ("ICO"). In the UK case, Facebook was penalized for unlawfully processing personal information of its users between 2007 and 2014, without obtaining sufficiently clear and informed consent. The fine imposed by ICO was also justified by Facebook's failure to keep its users' personal information secure, which meant that the personal data of 87 million Facebook users located in the UK, US and other countries were shared with a third-party company named GSR. It was determined that GSR later shared a subset of the data with other organizations, including SCL Group, the parent company of Cambridge Analytica - a company involved in political campaigning in the United States. Within this context, ICO established that Facebook had failed to take adequate and timely remedial action, involving deletion, despite the fact that it discovered such misuse of data in 2015 and it did not suspend the company from its platform until the year of 2018.To wrap up, AGCM's recent decision on Facebook appears to be the latest indicator that signifies competition and data protection enforcers' tendency to scrutinize big technology companies over data-related conducts. Thus, it seems that the big-tech companies have much to expect and learn from competition and data protection authorities all over the world.Footnotes1 As is known, Italian Competition Authority, Autorit Garante Della Concorrenza E Del Mercato ("AGCM"), had imposed a 3 million-euro fine on Whatsapp on 11 May 2017, for having forced its users to share their personal data with Facebook.2 http://en.agcm.it/en/media/press-releases/2018/12/Facebook-fined-10-million-Euros-by-the-ICA-for-unfair-commercial-practices-for-using-its-subscribers%E2%80%99-data-for-commercial-purposes[1]3   http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1130918.shtml[2]4   http://en.agcm.it/en/media/press-releases/2018/12/Facebook-fined-10-million-Euros-by-the-ICA-for-unfair-commercial-practices-for-using-its-subscribers%E2%80%99-data-for-commercial-purposes[3]5   https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/02/facebook-data-breach-social-network-could-face-eu-fine.html[4]6   https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/oct/03/facebook-data-breach-latest-fine-investigation[5]7   https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-eu-fine-163-billion-massive-data-breach-50-million-users-2018-10[6]8   https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-faces-potential-1-63-billion-fine-in-europe-over-data-breach-1538330906[7]The content of this article is intended to provide a general guide to the subject matter. urn:contentItem:5VR0-3KM1-F0JP-W546-00000-00Hefty fines for Big Tech2019-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Hefty fines for Big TechEXCLUSIVE Annika Smethurst

TECH titans such as Facebook and Google will be hit with hundreds of millions of dollars in fines by the Federal Government if they fail to keep our data safe.

As political pressure grows on social media and internet companies for broadcasting the Christchurch massacre, Prime Minister Scott Morrison will today announce record penalties for online giants who breach -privacy laws, declaring "the -internet cannot be a lawless -society".

The crackdown comes a week after Mr Morrison told The Sunday Mail he wanted companies such as Facebook and Twitter to take responsibility for broadcasting footage of New Zealand's worst-ever mass shooting.

Today's historic privacy shake-up will see the online -giants fined hundreds of millions of dollars - up from just $2.1 million - for serious data breaches or repeatedly flouting privacy laws.

Mr Morrison told The Sunday Mail tech titans must do the right thing with -people's information and stop hate content.

"They have had the smarts to build the technology and rake in the revenues, they can use these same smarts to keep Australians safe," he said.

The Sunday Mail can reveal next week's Federal Budget will include $25 million for Australia's privacy watchdog to investigate dodgy tech companies who illegally track web activity without consent or collate personal data and share with third parties.

Australia's Information Commissioner will also be given new powers to force the tech industry to take part in -investigations and improve -behaviour if caught mishandling data.

The new laws, to be introduced if the Coalition wins the election, will also boost the maximum penalties issued by the Australian regulator to either $10 million, three times the value of any benefit gained or 10 per cent of annual domestic turnover.

Regulators will be able to issue fines for the highest amount of those three amounts meaning Google could be slapped with a penalty as high as $102 million or $47 million for Facebook for doing the wrong thing, based on 2017 earnings.

The tough new approach brings Australia in line with European Union-wide privacy law, which came into effect last year.

Big tech operators that -refuse to co-operate with the Australian Information Commissioner or those that fail to change their behaviour will face additional penalties.Today's privacy crackdown comes ahead of a crucial meeting this week with Mr Morrison summoning tech giants to Canberra amid a global backlash following the viral spread of the Christchurch vision.

urn:contentItem:5SDH-K4Y1-F19C-X1CX-00000-00Heightened debate in US as EU privacy rules take effect2018-05-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYHeightened debate in US as EU privacy rules take effect

Amid a global scramble to comply with new EU data protections laws, the debate on privacy has intensified in the United States with some calling for similar measures for Americans, and others warning the rules could fracture the global internet.

US tech firms, and virtually all companies with online operations, will need to comply with the rules if their sites are used in the European Union, or face hefty financial penalties.

Some American firms, including news sites like the Los Angeles Times and New York Daily News, blocked access in the EU because they were unable to comply with the General Data Protection Regulation, which took effect Friday.

Other US websites have shut down entirely, and some have hired consultants to help shut off access for any users in Europe.

Large US tech firms have pledged compliance with the EU rules, and have in many cases promised to extend the same protections worldwide.

But legal challenges filed in Europe accused Google and Facebook of failing to abide by the new law.

- Why not in US? -

Some US activists argue that the implementation offers an opportunity to give more privacy and data protection benefits to Americans.

"We see no reason why US companies, as they strive to comply with the new European policies, cannot extend the GDPR standard to American consumers," said Katharina Kopp of the Center for Digital Democracy, one of 28 activist groups endorsing a letter in that vein to major US and global companies.

Senator Ed Markey and three fellow lawmakers introduced a resolution this week that would call on firms to offer the same protections of the European law in the US.

"The American people are going to wonder why they are getting second-class privacy protections," said Markey.

The law establishes the key principle that individuals must explicitly grant permission for their data to be used, and give consumers a right to know who is accessing their information and what it will be used for.

Companies can be fined up to 20 million euros ($24 million) or four percent of annual global turnover for violations.

- Cumbersome, confusing -

GDPR critics argue the law is confusing and cumbersome, and could lead to unintended effects on both sides of the Atlantic.

Daniel Castro of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a Washington think tank, called GDPR "a confusing and impractical set of rules" that offers consumers little benefit.

"Instead of hiring engineers, companies are hiring privacy lawyers," Castro said in a blog post with researcher Alan McQuinn.

Ryan Radia of the Competitive Enterprise Institute said that although GDPR was aimed at Big Tech, it is likely to strengthen the grip of large internet firms.

"This will result in greater market concentration, as small firms and startups will find it difficult to comply with the increased regulatory cost burden," Radia said.

Amy Webb, a fellow at Harvard's Nieman Foundation and founder of the Future Today Institute, warned the new law could lead to a "splinternet" with different kinds of data available in various regions of the world, and could be particularly cumbersome for news organizations.

"It's plausible within a decade, we could find ourselves stuck in a new digital divide, where many disparate splinternets behave and function differently, depending on where in the world the net is being accessed," she said in a blog post this week.

Webb said news organizations could find it especially difficult to comply because of the need for consent in organizing feeds and promoting content.

"The business model for news, already tenuous, could be further weakened," she said.

Henry Farrell, a George Washington University professor who follows transatlantic relations, said the entire business model of the tech sector could be at risk from GDPR.

"This is a fundamental attack on the 'two sided market' profit model that e-commerce companies have pioneered of providing services to individuals, while watching their behavior and feeding up access or data to advertisers," Farrell said in a tweet Friday.

The law establishes the key principle that individuals must explicitly grant permission for their data to be used, and give consumers a right to know who is accessing their information and what it will be used for.

Companies can be fined up to 20 million euros ($24 million) or four percent of annual global turnover for violations.

- Cumbersome, confusing -

GDPR critics argue the law is confusing and cumbersome, and could lead to unintended effects on both sides of the Atlantic.

Daniel Castro of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a Washington think tank, called GDPR "a confusing and impractical set of rules" that offers consumers little benefit.

"Instead of hiring engineers, companies are hiring privacy lawyers," Castro said in a blog post with researcher Alan McQuinn.

Ryan Radia of the Competitive Enterprise Institute said that although GDPR was aimed at Big Tech, it is likely to strengthen the grip of large internet firms.

"This will result in greater market concentration, as small firms and startups will find it difficult to comply with the increased regulatory cost burden," Radia said.

Amy Webb, a fellow at Harvard's Nieman Foundation and founder of the Future Today Institute, warned the new law could lead to a "splinternet" with different kinds of data available in various regions of the world, and could be particularly cumbersome for news organizations.

"It's plausible within a decade, we could find ourselves stuck in a new digital divide, where many disparate splinternets behave and function differently, depending on where in the world the net is being accessed," she said in a blog post this week.

Webb said news organizations could find it especially difficult to comply because of the need for consent in organizing feeds and promoting content.

"The business model for news, already tenuous, could be further weakened," she said.

Henry Farrell, a George Washington University professor who follows transatlantic relations, said the entire business model of the tech sector could be at risk from GDPR.

"This is a fundamental attack on the 'two sided market' profit model that e-commerce companies have pioneered of providing services to individuals, while watching their behavior and feeding up access or data to advertisers," Farrell said in a tweet Friday.

urn:contentItem:5SF6-0KR1-DYTM-932B-00000-00Heightened debate in US as EU privacy rules take effect.(Tech News)2018-05-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisHeightened debate in US as EU privacy rules take effect.(Tech News)

By Agence France-Presse

Amid a global scramble to comply with new EU data protections laws, the debate on privacy has intensified in the United States with some calling for similar measures for Americans, and others warning the rules could fracture the global internet.

US tech firms, and virtually all companies with online operations, will need to comply with the rules if their sites are used in the European Union, or face hefty financial penalties.

Some American firms, including news sites like the Los Angeles Times and New York Daily News, blocked access in the EU because they were unable to comply with the General Data Protection Regulation, which took effect Friday.

Other US websites have shut down entirely, and some have hired consultants to help shut off access for any users in Europe.

Large US tech firms have pledged compliance with the EU rules, and have in many cases promised to extend the same protections worldwide.

But legal challenges filed in Europe accused Google and Facebook of failing to abide by the new law.

Why not in US?

Some US activists argue that the implementation offers an opportunity to give more privacy and data protection benefits to Americans.

"We see no reason why US companies, as they strive to comply with the new European policies, cannot extend the GDPR standard to American consumers," said Katharina Kopp of the Center for Digital Democracy, one of 28 activist groups endorsing a letter in that vein to major US and global companies.

Senator Ed Markey and three fellow lawmakers introduced a resolution this week that would call on firms to offer the same protections of the European law in the US.

"The American people are going to wonder why they are getting second-class privacy protections," said Markey.

The law establishes the key principle that individuals must explicitly grant permission for their data to be used, and give consumers a right to know who is accessing their information and what it will be used for.

Companies can be fined up to 20 million euros ($24 million) or four percent of annual global turnover for violations.

Cumbersome, confusing

GDPR critics argue the law is confusing and cumbersome, and could lead to unintended effects on both sides of the Atlantic.

Daniel Castro of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a Washington think tank, called GDPR "a confusing and impractical set of rules" that offers consumers little benefit.

"Instead of hiring engineers, companies are hiring privacy lawyers," Castro said in a blog post with researcher Alan McQuinn.

Ryan Radia of the Competitive Enterprise Institute said that although GDPR was aimed at Big Tech, it is likely to strengthen the grip of large internet firms.

"This will result in greater market concentration, as small firms and startups will find it difficult to comply with the increased regulatory cost burden," Radia said.

Amy Webb, a fellow at Harvard's Nieman Foundation and founder of the Future Today Institute, warned the new law could lead to a "splinternet" with different kinds of data available in various regions of the world, and could be particularly cumbersome for news organizations.

"It's plausible within a decade, we could find ourselves stuck in a new digital divide, where many disparate splinternets behave and function differently, depending on where in the world the net is being accessed," she said in a blog post this week.

Webb said news organizations could find it especially difficult to comply because of the need for consent in organizing feeds and promoting content.

"The business model for news, already tenuous, could be further weakened," she said.

Henry Farrell, a George Washington University professor who follows transatlantic relations, said the entire business model of the tech sector could be at risk from GDPR.

"This is a fundamental attack on the 'two sided market' profit model that e-commerce companies have pioneered of providing services to individuals, while watching their behavior and feeding up access or data to advertisers," Farrell said in a tweet Friday.

CAPTION(S):

New EU privacy rules require online services such as Facebook to get consent for how personal data is accessed and shared. (AFP/File / Mladen ANTONOV / MANILA BULLETIN)

urn:contentItem:5S5J-VB01-DXH2-645W-00000-00Heitkamp Becomes First Democrat To Pledge Support For Pompeo As Secretary Of State; Prince William And Kate Middleton Welcome Royal Baby; Allegations Of Corruption At Top Of FBI & DOJ; 10Yr Yield Nears 3%2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKevin McCarthy, Paul Dougherty, Bud Cummins, Lee Carter, Mike MurphyNEWSFinancial042303cb.231Heitkamp Becomes First Democrat To Pledge Support For Pompeo As Secretary Of State; Prince William And Kate Middleton Welcome Royal Baby; Allegations Of Corruption At Top Of FBI & DOJ; 10Yr Yield Nears 3%Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, April 23rd. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Kicking off the busiest week in earnings season so far, one-third of the S&P 500 and a third of the Dow Industrials are reporting their first quarter this week. The market has turned higher, we're expecting a higher opening for the broader averages. DowIndustrials is up 17, S&P up a fraction, NASDAQ up 12.

Alphabet, the name to watch after the close tonight. It comes amid new concerns surrounding Google's data collection. Markets tumbled on Friday meanwhile, Apple is the big drag on the Dow after analysts report suggested smartphone sales could slow in the coming month. Take a look at European indices right here and the European indices are fractionally lower but have turned higher. Take a look, FT-100 is now up four points. CAC quarante is squeaking out a gain and the DAX index in Germany is up 1-1/2. Meanwhile over in Asia right across the board, the Hang Send, the big loser there down just about half a percent. Fractional move there as well.

Forging new ties of America's oldest ally. President Trump welcomes French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House today from trade to national security. Where are taking a look at what's on the agenda for the two world leaders. And then no official intelligence. Shocking new revelations this weekend surrounding the start of the FBI probe into the Trump campaign. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes telling me about his findings yesterday right here on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: We've long wanted to know what intelligence would you have that actually led to this investigation. So what we found now, after the investigators have reviewed it, is that in fact there was no intelligence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have the very latest from that investigation coming up. And then a new tune for Tencent, the Chinese streaming giant reportedly planning to go public. The company's mammoth evaluation coming up.

Plus, shook off. Taylor Swift losing her spot atop Spotify's most opening day stream. Who knocked the pop star from her thrown? All that coming up this morning. But first, we kick off this hour with a look at who is taking the gavel from Speaker of the House Paul Ryan after he retires. Speaker Ryan already throwing his support behind House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy as his successor. But does the California Congressman have enough votes? Joining me right now, the man himself, House Majority Leaders, California Congressman Kevin McCarthy. Great to see you, Congressman.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: Oh, thanks for having me back on.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. And congratulations that Paul Ryan endorsed you.

MCCARTHY: Well, it's how (INAUDIBLE) endorsed but the most important thing here is we have to make sure there is an opportunity for Republican to even run for Speaker next year. So, we have a work cut out for us, we have a great team in this conference, we're fighting hard. We got a lot of successes. But we've got a November election to go forward, so it's a little premature to everything.

BARTIROMO: Do you feel that you have the support from within your party to become the next speaker?

MCCARTHY: Well, we've got to make sure we have the opportunity to run there. I think that's the discussion with the conference. I feel confident, I'm humble that Paul and Steve would support me from that position but we've got a long way to go before that election to start.

BARTIROMO: So, let's talk about your priorities then. I mean, this $1.3 trillion omnibus bill, obviously it was a lot of upset because of all the spending, the White House is aiming to spend its recession requests to Congress early next despite Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is really dismissal of any claw back in spending. You've been leading this charge. Will we see a recession of that spending?

MCCARTHY: Well, remember, recessions are not about the omni and the whole reason why you even got into an omni, the House did all the work. We passed all 12 appropriation bills. The challenge was the minority in the Senate not voting against appropriation bill but voting against to even allow it to come up to be debated. You're allowing the minority to control what happens. And remember what happened to our military in the eight years cut by 20 percent. More of our men and women were dying in training than in combat. They were going to museums at times to get parts for our planes. And the world has not gotten 20 percent safer. But this is where the minority in the Senate withheld everything. We watched what they're doing to Pompeo, you watched what they're doing to all the appointment. They're plain politics. Now, a recession is much like what we've been using before. Remember our Congressional Review Acts that allows Senate just with 51 votes to repeal these burdensome regulations. We were successful 16 times. Rescissions have been used always before. Reagan used it more than 200 times, Bill Clinton used it more than 111 times. It's our ability to go back find ways, and I think, any member of Congress on any side of the aisle would want more ability to eliminate wasteful spending in government. So what we're doing is we're looking back not just when it comes to the omni, any place in government and it should be used many times. So it's our ability, you could pass it to the House and then you could the pass the bill in the Senate with 51 votes to be able to cut spending but nothing to do with the omni.

BARTIROMO: It makes perfect sense actually.

MCCARTHY: It does.

BARTIROMO: So why would McConnell be so dismissive about it?

MCCARTHY: The Democrats are trying to play another political game. This was common practice with Clinton, with Reagan, with Ford, with Carter, Obama did not use it. And so, from my point of view any opportunity we have to be able to save the taxpayers' money, we should work together and make it happen.

BARTIROMO: So you're still -- you're still working on that then?

(CROSSTALK)

MCCARTHY: I just had Mick Mulvaney in the office last week.

BARTIROMO: Do you think that the President just after signing it into law basically said well, now everyone is complaining about the omni and there's too much spending even, I understand the rescission not about omnibus per se but do you think he just decided, well, you know, that was a mistake. Did you feel that it will was a mistake after you signed it?

MCCARTHY: No. Because when you're looking at we're going forward in the military. What the mistake is allowing the minority in the Senate to control government. You should not be able to have a few in minority to vote to not even bring a bill up. Look at what they're doing when it comes to Mike Pompeo or any appointment. There is 1200 positions that have to be confirmed. At the rate they're going now, it will take 11 years. They are holding anybody up even at the end of the day, they may vote 100 percent for him. They are just trying to stop the government from being effective, efficient or accountable. And this President has looked at -- looked at what he's cut on regulations. Look how he used the Congressional Review Act, it's only been successful one time in history prior to President Trump. Look how much regulations he cut, look what he's done with V.A. And then when it comes to tax, you know, two million more people, have entered the workforce expanded it. Our unemployment claims are at 44-year low. Under Obama, our participation rate actually dropped from 65 to 62. It's going back up to more people in the workforce here. These are all positive things. So we're looking at every opportunity we can to not let the minority stop us and make -- actually put America First before politics.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that's why the markets are up 30 percent since the election and certainly this year you're seeing a lot of companies, animal spirits because of that tax plan. Do you think this resonates with people? Do you think the American people recognize that the tax cut plan was very positive, that moved the needle on economic growth and on jobs and at the same time, that the Senate is slow-walking all this stuff or the Democrats are trying to slow-walk everything in particular today with Pompeo and the vote.

MCCARTHY: Yes. It's -- to me it's more and more seeing it because I just watched the small business, I read the other day and Nevada got a bonus, so this one employee with John. It was -- it was a small visit, he just had a new child that had some difficulties. He was worried about how he was going to pay that bonus. 39 states have now their electrical bills lowered because of that tax cut. In one company 1.2 million employees now have a longer maternity leave because of that tax cut.

BARTIROMO: That's a big deal.

MCCARTHY: That's not Armageddon and those are not crumbs.

BARTIROMO: Right, right.

MCCARTHY: So there is -- and there wasn't one Democrat that stood up against Nancy Pelosi or Schumer and said I'm going to vote for the American public, I'm going to let keep -- let them keep more of what they earn. I'm going to make sure they get more bonuses, look at how more jobs created and think of all those billions of dollars that coming back from overseas and investing in America.

BARTIROMO: Will that be enough for you guys to keep the House majority? I mean, is this -- is this resonating to the extent that people are going to say I don't want to vote Democrat because they're going to raise my taxes. I don't want to vote Democrat because these are the policies that have been working. I mean, do you think people that's going to help you keep the majority?

MCCARTHY: Well, we got a lot more to do as well. That's one of the elements because there is a fundamental difference. The Democrats have come out with their tax plan to actually raise your taxes, and then they even make the debt even larger. They increased taxes by more than three trillion and they go six trillion on adding to the debt. They're not solving the problem. But look at what we've done with the V.A. You know, the G.I. bill was 15 years or you lose it? No, now it's a lifetime. Look what we've done when it comes to human trafficking, for more than eight- years we've tried to stop it. There were more 100 children are human trafficked in America. 70 percent of that happens online. We've been trying to stop back page, that just got shut down last week based upon the legislation that President Trump championed.

BARTIROMO: People are through increasingly worried about the debt. I mean, are you -- hypothetically speaking if you are the next speaker, are you going to have a program to rein in the spending on entitlements, rein in things like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid because we know those programs are going broke?

MCCARTHY: We have to. If you want to protect programs you got to reform them.

BARTIROMO: ok.

MCCARTHY: You almost need -- remember when we had a deal with the military, have like a rack of base realignment and closure where you brought everybody together that have one bill that would come down to the floor, we need that dealing with our debt because when Ronald Reagan was president, the discretionary spending, all those appropriations with 75 percent of the budget the mandatory was 25. Well, now that's 66 percent. It's (INAUDIBLE) so here you are, member of Congress, you vote for all 12 appropriation bills, you put it in direction but that's a small element of one-third of the government. And if you're not getting to the real root of the problem here you're not going to be able to have those entities for a future generation to support.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You're absolutely right. All right. Let me ask you about -- you mentioned Mike Pompeo, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee expected to vote against endorsing Pompeo, the nomination of the CIA Director Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state. This -- just in middle of all this happens with North Korea, North Dakota Senator Heidi Heitkamp emerging as the first Democrat to throw his support behind Pompeo. Your reaction to this opposition at the very moment in time that we're talking about SIS possibly returning, North Korea, Iran and the threats are only getting worse.

MCCARTHY: Pure politics. Look at, this is an individual I served with. He went to West Point, one of the first in his to graduate. You watch what he did in the House and in Intel Committee. But then he gets confirmed to be the head of the CIA. So, if those who didn't know him but they voted for him there, watch the job that he did there. He only expanded his ability and look what we're dealing with with North Korea what he's able to do so far. I think this is playing politics and they need to stop it because it's jeopardizing our country in a really critical time.

BARTIROMO: We heard stunning claims earlier, Congressman, about this Russia probe, the chairman of the House Intel Committee Devin Nunez joining me yesterday revealing that the results of his review is the beginning of the Trump campaign probe? Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: What we found after the investigators have reviewed it is that in fact there was no intelligence, now we're trying to figure out as you know, we are investigating the state department, we think there's some major irregularities at the state at state department.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So Nunes investigating state department to find out how the FBI got information about former Trump campaign advisor George Padopoulos. Your thoughts on this investigation even launching with no official intelligence.

MCCARTHY: Well, one thing you know about this investigation, it started out saying there was some collusion, no one has found it. I don't know why this investigation continues onward. And remember House Intelligence did, it separate but co-equal. And how long have they had to fight to get any of the information, not only their committee but Judiciary and others to fight to have the information, so it could be co-equal to look at these problems going forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, that's what we're certainly following as well. By the way, Kate Middleton has had her baby. We're going to get that breaking news in a moment.

MCCARTHY: That is breaking news.

BARTIROMO: That is breaking news. But real quick on France, the President is welcoming the French President to the White House for three days. You're going to be at that state dinner.

MCCARTHY: I will be there tomorrow night but, you know, there's a special place in my heart for France and should be for all Americans because they were there in the creation of our country and our -- and our battle to create this country, they supported us, maybe because they didn't like the England or not but they were there at the time hanging in -- hanging in the Capital inside chambers is Lafayette.

BARTIROMO: And Macron and Trump seem to have good rapport.

MCCARTHY: That's a thing that America doesn't quite understand this President. He's been so successful but what he is really successful on, relationships. They may report something. I have been with him so many times. These world leaders call him, they admire this man, they support him and have a great relation even if they have a difference of opinion. They work with him.

BARTIROMO: Well, you (INAUDIBLE) you have a good relationship with the President and it's one of the things that people like and certainly his supporters because you've supported him and tried to execute his plans. A lot of your colleagues haven't, they've been never-Trumpers.

MCCARTHY: I think that's wrong, you know. You have a campaign for who you want but when the election is over, let's put the country first and that's what I watched with this President. And it doesn't matter some support or not, he works with them. And he's debate some great -- look at what's happening in North Korea. Look what's happening to our economy when more people are able to work, unemployment at 4.1 percent. Look what's happening when it comes to more people keeping what their own money what they have or what changes happen to V.A. There's so much more we can do if people would work together to put the country first.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Great point. Congressman, good to see you.

MCCARTHY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Kevin McCarthy joining us there. The Majority Leader. That breaking news, Kate Middleton, wife of Prince Williams has given birth to baby boy, weighing in at eight pounds, seven ounces. It is the couple's third child. Kensington palace says both mother and baby are doing well. Kate Middleton delivers a baby boy. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Police are intensifying their search for the Waffle House shooter. Cheryl Casone with the details now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: Maria, police are still looking for 29-year-old Travis Reinking who opened fire at the suburban national restaurant before a hero customer brought an end to the chaos.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES SHAW, JR., WAFFLE HOUSE HERO: I locked and I made up my mind because there's no way to lock that door. That if it was going to come down to it he is going to have to work -- to work to kill me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: James Shaw prevented further tragedy suffering only a minor injury. Police say Reinking is armed and dangerous and national public schools are in lockdown mode this morning. And we have now learned the shooter had a previous run-in with police, he was arrested last year for being in a restricted area near the White House. The four people who were killed had been identified. Authorities say they are Taurean Sanderlin, Joe Perez, Akilah DaSilva, and DeEbony Groves.

Well, cooler company Yeti is the latest company to separate ties with the National Rifle Association. The NA -- NRA, excuse me, reportedly sent out an e-mail to its members blasting Yeti saying the decision was not sportsmanlike. Yeti hasn't not said why it's parting ways with the NRA. Several companies, Enterprise, Hertz, Delta, United Airlines have all cut ties with the NRA in response to public outcry for gun control following the Florida school shooting in February that left 17 people dead.

Well, the late first lady Barbara Bush buried over the weekend at a gated plot in George H.W. Presidential Library in College Station, Texas. She is now near the grave of her daughter Robin who died from leukemia when she was just three years old. The grave site is going to be open to the public starting this morning. The Bush family did share photos from the private ceremony, hundreds of family and friends giving a final farewell. The day brought together four former presidents, the President Bushes as see here as well as bill Clinton, Barack Obama, the first ladies also there including Melania Trump.

And an attribute to his life's commitment to literacy, former President Bush wore a pair of socks decorated with stacks of colorful books. OK. Maria, you brought us the breaking news, it's a boy, baby number three for Kate and Prince Williams. Finally here, we just the announcement. The royal baby weighing in at -- get this, eight pounds, seven ounces. Prince William was by his wife's side when the baby was delivered. Fifth in line to the throne now. This baby is behind siblings Prince George and Prince Charlotte. His name has not been announced yet. We probably have to wait a little bit for that. A lot of well wishers looking at this live pictures at London obviously. Have been camped outside the hospital for at least two weeks and of course now there's a ton of buzz over in London. So happy news. Ahead of the royal wedding by the way which is coming up as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Congratulations to them. Thank you so much, Cheryl. China's largest music streaming company reportedly exploring going public. How Tencent music could follow in Spotify's footsteps, that's coming up. And then the rise of Artificial Intelligence. New ways the technology could Transform the workplace. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Thinking beyond Alexa, Amazon reportedly working on a plan to build a robot for your home. The technology titan plans to start testing the new machines later this year. According to Bloomberg, the robots can move from room to room using tech similar to driverless cars. Just another example of how A.I. technology has the potential to transform your life. Joining us right now is the chief technology and innovation officer of Accenture, Paul Dougherty. Good to see you, Paul. Thank you so much for joining us.

PAUL DOUGHERTY, CHIEF TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION OFFICER, ACCENTURE: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: And you wrote a whole book about these human machines, Reimagining Work in the Age of A.I. How has it reimagined work?

DOUGHERTY: Yes. You know, we have this narrative around A.I. We hear about it these days and we think about A.I. taking over the human race, taking all of our jobs and beating us on all games and taking all our fun away. And we think that's the wrong narrative for A.I. What A.I. is really about is that it's a set of rules for companies in terms of how to be more competitive, how to drive more efficiency and how to drive growth and create a new business models and we don't talk enough about that and who wrote the book as guidance for executives and how to apply A.I. to transform their business and also how to do it in a way that represents the right way to use people and the capabilities of people to drive -- you know, to drive that growth and to use the technology worth it.

BARTIROMO: But it is taking away jobs. Not to be, you know, a fearmonger but when you do things more productive and you can do things easier from a robot standpoint, you're going to do it, right?

DOUGHERTY: Right. Absolutely. And so, A.I. is no different than any other technology and the fact that it, you know, every technology creates efficiencies and allows us to do things more effectively. A.I. is going to be no different. And there's a report recently from the OECD that talks about on the order of 14 percent of jobs being, you know, threatened by A.I. We think that's' about right.

BARTIROMO: Fourteen percent?

DOUGHERTY: About 14 percent. And another third of jobs beyond that being transformed significantly by A.I. and that's probably about right also. So, the issue is not that we don't have enough jobs because we're talk about many, many new types of jobs being created by companies. The issue is how do we prepare people with the right skills for these jobs because some will be displaced more quickly and that's why when decision we've made with the book is we're donating all the proceeds of the book to nonprofits and organizations that are helping with the rescaling challenge effectively for midcareer professionals. So we think that's where the challenge is. And we don't have all the answers to that but that' s what we think, we as business in society needs to deal with a little bit more effectively.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: And it's not the skills that some people might think looking down the road, we've talked about this, it's not computer programming, math and science, ultimately it's going to be humanities and ethics and areas like that kind of the arts if you will, because we're going to have to decide right, again. How do you -- what is OK for a robot to do in your life?

DOUGHERTY: Yes. Exactly right. We talk in the book about six new categories of jobs that we think represent millions and millions of jobs in the new economy and we call it the missing middle because we don't think that people are thinking about these jobs enough today is such missing in the current discussion. And these jobs are the key to really reshaping business and, you know, thinking about how we build the right skills in people. And broadly, we could talk about this market. There's two categories of jobs. There's one set of jobs which is all about where people are needed to help machines, you know, like you describe, implementing A.I. responsibly and reflecting the right behavior. It's trading A.I. properly. That's one entire category of jobs. The other set of jobs are jobs where A.I. and machines and robots help people work effectively, increase productivity up to 40 percent from the research that we've done. And we use phrase that gives humans superpower, that gives us better tools to do our jobs and allows people to do new things. And that's -- those categories of jobs are where we think the opportunity is.

MCDOWELL: Elon Musk said recently with the production staffers on the Model 3 that he underestimated the value of human. That he overestimated the ability to basically use robots in manufacturing.

DOUGHERTY: That's a great example. Elon said that humans are underrated, it was his quote. And they're introducing more humans in the factories. They found they were overautomated, they were overindustrialized. Mercedes did the same with their S-class factory. BMW did the same in their factory. We're seeing the same another none, you know, robotic, nonmanufacturing scenarios where people are needed to apply creativity. People can improvise. People have the ability to communicated in a emotive response. And those types of things are necessary for the next generation of work that we're moving to.

BARTIROMO: Really interesting stuff. Paul, thank you so much. Thanks for joining us.

DOUGHERTY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you. Paul Dougherty there. Human Machine is name of the book. Reimaging Work In The Age Of A.I. Coming up. Dozens of southwest flights are canceled for engine inspections following the fatal explosion last week. New delays across the country to tell you about. Then ex-FBI Director Jim Comey reportedly heads to Amazon headquarters now to promote his book this morning. The media tour backlash continues, back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, April 23rd, your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Markets turning higher this morning, Futures now indicating a higher of opening for the broader averages. Dow Industrials set to open up about 40 points, NASDAQ up 25. This, after Treasury yields rose hitting equity market on Friday. The major indices all closed lower last week on the day, on Friday, and are now negative for 2018.

Global markets this morning look like this, here too, you have a bit of a turnaround, FT-100 is down just a fraction, but the CAC Quarante is up six points, and the DAX Index is up 14. In Asia overnight, declines across the board, worse performer: Hong Kong, half a percent lower.

Maverick meets Maverick, that's how French President Emmanuel Macron is framing his three-day visit and meeting with President Trump. He also previewed his message to lawmakers ahead of his speech before a joint session of Congress.

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE: I think the U.S. to be able as versatile to play for peace, in different regions of the world, and especially Middle East. So, I will advocate for -- in front of the Congress for that, which means, playing all together, you know, to reduce the influence of some rogue states and very tactic leaders.

BARTIROMO: We take you to the straight ahead on that. Meanwhile, former FBI Director Jim Comey takes a show on the road; he is set to speak before Amazon employees this morning. Earnings in focus in business this morning. Alphabet kicking things off for technology, after the close tonight. The Chinese streaming giant reportedly gearing up for an IPO. We've got details. And then, Taylor Swift has been dethroned. Find out who took her Spotify streaming record coming up this morning. All of that coming up this Monday morning. But first, our top story this half an hour, new ties with America's oldest ally. French President Emmanuel Macron making his first state visit this week. Macron and President Trump have a packed three-day agenda, talking about everything from trade to global tensions. Blake Burman at the White House right now with the very latest. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. The first state dinner of the Trump administration indeed goes to Emmanuel Macron of France. He will arrive later this afternoon, and then the first couples will head to nearby Mt. Vernon for dinner tonight at George Washington's home. The policy discussion will take place in earnest tomorrow, and trade and tariffs will be front and center.

MACRON: I hope he will -- we will not implement these new tariffs, and he will decide to -- for an exemption for European Union. You don't make trade war with your ally.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: But he said that he is going to implement --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The administration does point out that France is exempt to steel and aluminum tariffs, at least for now. Raj Shah saying on the show earlier this morning that the discussions will move beyond trade as well.

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: We want to deepen the relationship, we want to continue the trading partnership, we want to talk about security. You mentioned Iran, so there's a whole host of issues that both President Macron and President Trump want to talk about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Maria, Syria will also be a focus of these discussions. The White House does not push back on the notion that it was Macron who convinced President Trump to take action inside that country. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right. Blake, thank you so much. Blake Burman with the latest there. Meanwhile, shocking new revelations this morning about how the FBI probe into the Trump campaign really began. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes shares his newest findings on the investigation into accusations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 election. Here's what he told me yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NUNES: So, we've long wanted to know what intelligence did you have that actually led to this investigation? So, what we found now after the investigators have reviewed it, is that, in fact, there was no intelligence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is former U.S. Attorney and Avenue Strategies Partner, Bud Cummins. Bud, good to see you. Thanks for joining us.

BUD CUMMINS, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY AND AVENUE STRATEGIES PARTNER: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to this, this morning, that Chairman Nunes says there was actually no official intelligence used to launch that investigation into the Trump campaign.

CUMMINS: I think it's significant. I mean, I saw that piece yesterday, on your show, I -- you know, I said wow! It's -- it draws us back, and I think not enough attention has been placed back to the time that this investigation started. And who knew all the facts and who didn't know all facts in the process of starting the, the appointment of special prosecutor. I think people need to be held accountable for withholding information about what actually happened, because it really looks like that politicians on the left, fraudulently put this information into the stream of commerce, and the FBI ran with it, and nobody seems to want to hold those people accountable.

BARTIROMO: So, so, maybe that was the insurance policy that Peter Strzok was texting Lisa Page about? Just constant --

CUMMINS: I think that's exactly what that is.

BARTIROMO: Investigation after investigation, I mean, that's what I think, what do you think?

CUMMINS: I think that -- well, I think that's true, and I want to ask you all, you know, if someone proposed that we go to the summer convention in the next election cycle, and as part of the process, each party nominated some lawyer that it in the event they lose the election, that person will be immediately vested with investigatory powers and have access to grand jury to just perpetually investigate the winner. I don't think anybody would be for that, but I don't know how that's any different than what we have here, for a special prosecutor who has put in place apparently on totally fraudulent information that people knew was fraudulent. And now it just -- it's going on in the perpetuity. I mean, what do we do about that? And I really don't have answer.

BARTIROMO: Extraordinary.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: It is extraordinary. But one of the things that I find fascinating talking to voters is that they say, it almost is doesn't matter how this all started, it matters now what they find. And that's a pretty dangerous mind-set. So, can you tell me how you share with the implications of what this means if, if the process totally changes as a result of this?

CUMMINS: Well, I mean, you know, this is this happens in typical investigations out of U.S. Attorneys officers all the time. You start in one area, you trip up some other information, that you didn't know about when you started, and you pursue it because you can't come in to look for the drugs and find a dead body and ignore it. I mean, you have to do what you got to do. But the question I think is, are all these new issues that the special prosecutor may or may not find, to start looking into, are -- do they still fall into the scope of the need for a special prosecutor? Can't most of these things be looked at through Department of Justice and through the U.S. Attorney's offices in the typically setup? And I don't really know a mechanism to shut down as special prosecutor until special process himself comes forward and says I'm done. And I'm not sure that's the way we want it to be set up.

BARTIROMO: But I mean, knowing what we know, in terms of the bias at the top of the FBI and the Department of Justice during election, knowing what we know that DNC paid for dossier to use to spy on the Trump campaign, and knowing that there was no other intelligence used to launch that campaign. Shouldn't -- I mean, shouldn't Robert Mueller be looking at these things? Is this going to be part of his investigation? Or are you saying, this investigation the special council should be shut down?

CUMMINS: Well, I think all these things can be looked at by Robert Mueller, or the IOG, or investigators in a criminal context out of the Department of Justice. I think that the main point from what you said that I'm interested in is the people really want the truth. This lock her up, lock him up mentality, this weaponization of politics trying to incarcerate people, as part of the political process I think is very dangerous and could lead to really bad place. We really want truth, and I think, from my money, we could go immunize all these people and say, look, you tell the truth, we're not going to prosecute anybody -- General Flynn, Papadopoulos, McCabe, Comey. Just tell us the truth and let's take a look at what happens so we don't repeat this. That's what's most important, I think, for the American people, but I don't think that that's possible. I mean, they've already gotten the guilty plea out of General Flynn, and I don't know how you take a guilty plea from General Flynn not charge Andrew McCabe. I mean, it's really a mess, and it has started by bad leadership at the Department of Justice and the FBI.

MCDOWELL: Do you think, Bud, it's Dagen McDowell that those charges will happen? Again, because we've talked about people -- just Martha Stewart as one example that we keep using, she lied to FBI and she went to prison. And you got Andy McCabe who was out there writing that editorial along with his wife in Washington Post, basically saying that it was a witch hunt, and he told the truth, and he actually -- he said he misremembered, I think, might've been the word that he used. But, again, he lied. He lied under oath three times according to the inspector general. Should you think he will be prosecuted?

CUMMINS: It's a very difficult question, but I think that if you look at the president, I've seen FBI prosecute lots of people who didn't commit any other crimes for lying under oath one time; he lied under oath three times. And you know -- but moreover, again, the truth is what's important to me, and the truth is that that guy should've never been deputy director of the FBI. One thing that jumped out of me in that IOG report was not criminal conduct, was how he threw his supervisors in New York and Washington under the bus when he'd leaked the information and then he called and chewed them out on numerous instances for not managing the leaks that he was leaking. That kind of leadership is, is, well, it's disturbing, to say the least, there are other words could I use that we probably shouldn't use on T.V.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Bud, it's Mike Murphy. I agree with your point that the -- when left versus right, real loser here is American public. So, maybe your idea of just granting immunity to people out there, just so we can get to the bottom of this, put it behind us and not have to go through a situation like this that drags on forever, and really hurts the country, and hurts citizens of this country.

BARTIROMO: Well, but that's another thing. I mean, the Clinton people did get immunity, right? Cheryl Mills -- even though they lied.

CUMMINS: Well, there wasn't even an investigation. I mean, you can't call what happened there an investigation. They, they touched and they moved on. They wrote a memo to dismiss it all before they'd done 17 interviews. That was a joke. There was a Hillary Clinton fan club, on the fifth floor of the FBI. And whether Jim Comey was part of it or not, I think, what he needs to write about in his book is how he was -- his management was -- abilities were unable to detect that his entire management team was in Hillary Clinton's pocket.

BARTIROMO: And abusing their power. Abuse of power.

MCDOWELL: You what the story is, though? It's very clear from listening to Jim Comey on this book tour, they just assumed Hillary Clinton was going to win, but they want to keep their jobs, they weren't going to put the hammer down on her because they were sure she was going to win, and then they didn't want the Clinton ire and the Clinton machine coming after them when she did win. That's the real backstory.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right.

MCDOWELL: -- said out loud or not.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right. And here Jim Comey is writing a book and on a book tour, rolling on with Amazon headquarters today, Bud. He's reportedly speaking for free to employees there, the fired FBI director's book: "A Higher Loyalty", top seller on Amazon. The company is taking drastic measures to avoid posts by people who did not read the book? So, Amazon is only allowing "verified buyers" to review best seller. It's just incredible.

(LAUGHTER)

CUMMINS: Yes, it is incredible, and you know, I'm more on that because as former colleague of Jim Comey, he was looked up to, and he worked very hard, frankly, to cultivate this stellar reputation in the law enforcement community. And his actions over the last two years, and especially, you know, tapping it all for this book tour have kind of ruined that.

BARTIROMO: And how aggressive the Democrats? They're actually now suing the Republicans for exactly the reason and what they did during the 2016 election by protecting Hillary. Bud, it's good to see you, sir. Thank you.

CUMMINS: Thank you. Good to talk to you. Bye.
